abstract: The overall objective of this SBIR project is to design and demonstrate an enabling technology for the power supply of micro unmanned aerial vehicles.  This MAUV power technology is lightweight and very high in energy density.  IGR will develop a stainless steel/ductile-ceramic-composite SOFC, using pre-loaded carbon fuel, to meet the power supply needs of MUAVs.  The technology provides for long endurance flights with zero maintenance requirements.  The use of powered C(s) in the fuel plenum of each cell eliminates all fuel tanks, pumps, lines and processing.  The maintenance free shelf-life of all solid-state system is essentially unlimited.
title: Low Weight, Zero Maintenance Long Endurance SOFC for MUAV

abstract: Earlier works have been extended to develop electronic packages for use under corrosive and high temperature environments.  Most silicon-based semiconductor devices can operate only below 300C. New developments of amorphous silicon carbide packages have attracted wide interest due to the capability of tailoring electronic, optical and structural properties for microhybrid and optoelectronic device application under extreme environments.  The objective of this proposed project is to develop a manufacturing process with a silicon carbide package.  Selection of materials and the design of the package will be discussed.  The incorporation of the Navy designed package as a prototype design for developing prototype commercial packages will also be mentioned.
title: High Temperature Package for Recently Developed Silicon Carbide

abstract: A viable component-ware technology infrastructure is starting to emerge industry-wide.  The basis of this infrastructure is a critical mass of the leading platform vendors adopting an object-based distributed computing specification:  Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA).  We propose to leverage emerging distributed object-based distributed computing frameworks, initially CORBA, and advance it by designing a protocols for fault-tolerant space systems.  We propose to advance current CORBA technology through the development of two key innovations:  1) run-time (dynamic) or compile-time (static) semantic-based composition and synthesis of reusable software components and 2) the ability to compose fault-tolerant services from groups of components.  Object group topologies will enable the deployment of fault-tolerant services based on object replication and migration management.  Critical operations will be able to continue in a gracefully degraded fashion if any one copy of a system element fails.  The long-range goal of this proposed work is to overcome barriers to building and deploying fault-tolerant systems from verified, reusable software components.  Benefits:  Significant reductions in time-do-development, cost of system testing and requirements validation will drive the initial market demand for reusable, fault-tolerant object groups.  Early adopter markets are mission-critical domains such as DOD analysis and command support, satellite and space control operations, capital market (trading floor) decision support information systems, government and commercial logistics management and medical information systems.|
title: Imagery Exploitation Software Component Factory

abstract: IKOS Systems proposes to integrate a high performance, IEEE VHDL WAVES input-output capability into their VHDL mixed-level simulation environment.  This will enhance WAVES ability to effectively support large, complex digital electronic designs.  The interface will have two elements.  First, a Compiler for WAVES data into a compact binary format for input into both the VHDL simulation engine and the gate level simulation accelerator inside the IKOS's VHDL mixed-level simulation environment.  This will offer the user the choice of running IEEE WAVES within the VHDL kernel, or as a more efficient, compiled binary format that will be directly injectable into the simulation environment at run time.  Second, a Generator that will output simulation result vectors in a WAVES data set format.  This will improve the ease of WAVES creation, debug, and transport.  These two mechanisms form the foundation for run time execution of IEEE WAVES simulation data within a commercially viable VHDL product that has the performance and capacity required for large and complex electronic system designs.  The Phase I objectives are to validate the technical feasibility of this approach, and to produce the preliminary design concepts for the WAVES Compiler and WAVES output generator.
title: WAVES Compiler/Generator for Optimum Performance and Transportability

abstract: This study will investigate the applicability of computer modeling   and simulation to the analysis of personnel radio frequency (RF)   radiation hazards.  The final goal of this project is to design,   develop, and produce a Windows based analysis tool to assist in the   evaluation of RF hazards near an antenna.  It will perform all   routine analysis calculations, as well as near-field power density   predictions to determine the hazard zone around that antenna in   3-dimensional space.  It will also contain all reference material   needed by an analyst.  Most hazard analysis of RF systems start   with a theoretical prediction of the hazard distance. This hazard   distance is the distance to the point where the power density of   the antenna's main beam falls off to the Permissible Exposure Limit   (PEL) or Maximum Permissible Exposure (MPE) level.  Presently, most   analysts use simple inverse square law calculations and ignore   near-field effects.  This method frequently produces a gross   overestimation of the hazard potential of the source.  Antennas to   be modeled in this SBIR include aperture (dish) antennas, wire   antennas (dipole, monopole, yagi, log-periodic, curtain, etc),   antenna arrays, and point sources.  The option of including the   effects of a ground plane will be included.
title: Development of Automated Radio Frequency Radiation (RFR) Standard

abstract: The Computationally Intelligent ATR Architecture (CIAA) for SAR imagery will be driven by both point (scatter) and region features.  I-MATH has previously developed point extraction algorithms.  SAIC will suggest various region measurements, again drawing upon the current results of the MSTAR program.  All of the raw features, both point and region associated, including the (x,y) hash point coordinates, will be input into the System Dynamics "e" Genetic Algorithm program, so as to produce two sets of evolved features.  The first set will be tested with fuzzy logic rules (also evolved by the Genetic Algorithm) to generate an index to the Geometric Hashing.  The primary index will be target pose (3D orientation) and possibly some estimates of target class.  This will decisively reduce the size of the search space for the geometric hashing; hence a much smaller group of models will need to be matched.  Currently, the hash matching determines which point model is closest to the point representation of the unknown live image.  A number of metrics are computed, including percent of live and model points matched, live and model basis pair distances, average point mismatch distance, and roation angle dissimilarity.  These metrics are applied with ad hoc thresholds and rules to determine the match.  For the CIAA, we would instead use a second fuzzy logic rule set, again derived by the Genetic Algorithms, to compute more efficient match decision metrics.  The CIAA represents an innovative structure for both improving ATR performance and simplfying the model search strategy.  Notwithstanding this innovation, its components are all proven algorithms with which we are developing other successful ATR systems.  In Phase I, we will provide detailed estimates of the CIAA's performance by benchmarking it to the geometric hashing-only algorithm.  In Phase II, we will extend the CIAA evaluation by comparing its performance to other SAR ATR's, to especially include the MSTAR algorithm suite.
title: Computational Intelligence Approaches to Automatic Target Recognition

Integrated Microtransducer Electronics Corp.

Thin-film transformers have many applications in miniaturized power systems and control curcuits but are unreliable or unusable at low frequencies.  In previous work, multilayer, thin magnetic films have been developed that offer the potential for eliminating this problem.  The transformer is based on an active giant magnetoresistive (GMR) device that will work even down to DC.  The input is completely isolated from the output, and there is no resistive path between the two.  Both voltage and current can be stepped either up or down.  Because of its large bandwidth, the transformer is suitable for both analog and some digital circuitry.  It can be fabricated on the same substrate as other GMR-based logic circuits and memory elements.  Phase I will demonstrate the feasibility of using these films to develop useful micron-scale transformers through design, calculation, fabrication, and testing.

Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:  Silicon technology has no microtransformers.  GMR technology, on the other hand, is intrinsically able to implement such transformers, thereby enabling broader circuit-design capabilities for a variety of communications, measurement and control circuits, as well as for a broad spectrum of new applications.
title: Thin-Film, Micron-Scale Transformers

abstract: The goal of this SBIR effort is to develop force-reflecting joystick interfaces to assist individuals with impaired motor skills.  Individuals whose hand or arm movements have superimposed non-voluntary tremor or who suffer from spastic motion stand to benefit enormously.  Through design and technology improvements to joystick controllers, formerly impossible tasks, such as steering a wheelchair or interacting with a graphical computer display, become feasible.  By integrating force feedback technologies into wheelchair stick controllers, spastic hand motion can be suppressed by compensation, allowing underlying intentional movements to be expressed.  Specifically, the mechanical impedance of the joystick will be modulated through hardware and software.  These programmable impedance changes can be used to create 'virtual fixtures' to dynamically reduce the set of selectable positions of the joystick, thereby simplifying its use.  This Phase I project will explore designs for assistive force feedback controllers based on Immersion Corp's existing force reflecting products, resulting in a commercialization proposal for Phase II.  We will implement our designs and test force feedback algorithms for their value in assisting manual targeting and piloting tasks through formal empirical studies at the Ohio Supercomputer Center and the Palo Alto, CA VA Rehabilitation R&D Center.
title: Reconfigurable Haptic Interface System

abstract: Haptic feedback has great potential to enhance human interaction with virtual environments. superior training, enhanced presence, and increased intuitiveness are proven advantages of force feedback.  While highly effective, haptic sensations are rarely incorporated into virtual reality systems.  This is due to a lack of reconfigurable hardware and software that can be adapted to address diverse tasks with minimum development effort.  Immersion Corporation proposes the development of a modular hardware system and software environment which will allow developers to easily build virtual environments which possess haptic (tactile and kinesthetic) qualities.  The proposed system will allow users to compose new haptic sensations and further, to implement, test, share, and even collaboratively re-design their associated haptic percepts.  Fundamentally, this effort will accomplish the following:  define the hardware modules and software development tools used to generate the haptic components of virtual objects so that force feedback can be rapidly and effectively applied to a broad range of virtual reality tasks.  The resulting reconfigurable haptic interface system will satisfy multiple tasks and will support virtual testing of weapon and vehicular systems.  The proposed system will greatly enhance the realism and/or effectiveness of virtual environments.  This includes virtual reality, scientific visualization systems, computer aided design packages, medical simulation and training equipment, vehicle simulators, and entertainment applications.  An adaptable and capable software engine will catalyze the commercialization of haptics.
title: Reconfigurable Haptic Interface System

abstract: Human cytochrome P450s play a prominent role in the metabolism of steroids, fatty acids,eicosanoids, drugs, phytochemicals and toxins. Specific enzymes can activate carcinogens, can beinduced, stimulated or inhibited by various compounds, and can be one of several polymorphic forms.Although the enzymic properties measured using animal P450s are suggestive of what might beexpected from closely related human enzymes, these reagents/systems are nonetheless imprecisepredictors of the catalytic range and sensitivity associated with a particular human P450. We areaddressing this deficiency. The long range goal is the development of suitable reagents and assaysystems that can readily evaluate human P450 mediated metabolism. A method for producing sitespecific, high affinity, inhibitory antibodies will be valuated. These antibodies will be capable ofrecognizing both denatured and native, membrane bound P450 antigen. Such reagent will allow reactionhenotyping of specific P450 forms in a complex mixture such as human liver microsomes and providea valuable tool for assessing changes in tissue oncentration resulting from exposure to inducing agents.In addition, a method is described for producing a panel of expressed epitopes form closely relatedP450s that will be obtained from various human cDNA libraries. This epitope panel will be used to assesantibody cross reactivity as well as to identify new and previously uncharacterized P450 enzymes.These immunoregents will help delineate the myriad possibilities for interaction between this complexenzyme family and a vast array of pharmaceutical, environmental and dietary compounds. Thisknowledge can be essential for predicting drug-drug interactions and the impact of genetic deficiencieson toxicity.

Diagnosis and treatment evaluation has been hampered by the probrelatively rare events. An ambulatory monitor recording body position (AMP) largely resolves this pralso be used for Restless Legs (RL) and other sleep disorders requiring separating events in relatiositting or lying. Medical conditions, particularly osteoporosis, involving standing times for treatmAMP to support compliance and assess treatment efficacy. The AMP provides an enabling technology forclinical evaluations in these areas. Building an easy-to-use miniature AMP recording data every 30-6several days requires development of a special 2-plane, passive sensor to be integrated with the IMSrecording technology. Phase I involves building four prototype monitors and field testing them withsleepwalkers and patients with RL. Phase II will include improved AMP design, clinical evaluation anactivity monitors. A commercial AMP will also be developed to both display minutes of standing/walkipatients and sound a loud alarm for sleepwalkers.

abstract: A primary objective is the development of digital x-ray systems that can be used to minimize x-ray film and chemicals use at Air Force aircraft maintenance facilities.  The review of existing and in-development x-ray systems will result in a meaningful comparison of technical capabilities and ease of field use, and for the cost justification that will be necessary for field level implementation.  The x-ray test piece proposed for digital system comparisons will provide images of typical aircraft x-ray NDI applications, such as crushed core, water intrusion and adhesive variables, plus quantitative data on contrast sensitivity and spatial resolution.  Information concerning Air Force field location x-ray inspection applications and x-ray film use will be analyzed to make recommendation for cost-effective digital x-ray systems.  An innovative addition will be a review of advantages of digitial x-ray imaging, in terms of wide dynamic range images that can easily be processed, archived, retrieved, transferred and compared with other inspection results.  Advantages for digital systems include reduced costs for film and fewer environmental problems due to process chemicals.  The program will lead to signficant improvement in the efficiency and quality of field level aircraft x-ray inspection.
title: Electronic, Digital X-Radiologic Imaging Systems for Field Inspections

abstract: In this Phase I program, ISP, Inc. proposes to design, develop, and deliver a low cost hot gas valve to MICOM for testing in their advanced tactical missile propulsion program.  The proposed valve is designed to provide continuous throttling of 2000 degrees F. fuel-rich solid propellant gas over a mass flow ratio of 5:1 with a maximum flow rate of 1 lbm/sec.  The valve design is based on the axially translating pintle which controls flow by varying nozzle throat ara.  To achieve the desired low cost, the valve comprises commercially-available control components such as the actuator and the servovalve and features a unique hydraulic power supply that derives its power from gas generator chamber pressure.  The concept is scaleable over the desired 0.1 to 50 lbm/sec mass flow rate range and is compatible with conventional nozzle materials as evidenced by previous pintle nozzle development which has demonstrated a flow rate range of less than 0.1 to over 1000 lbm/sec and gas temperatures up to 6000 degrees F.  ISP, Inc. is proposing a six-month program at the conclusion of which a heavyweight hot gas valve will be delivered to MICOM with sufficient spare parts to support a minimum of five advanced propulsion tests.  Prior to delivery, ISP, Inc. will verify valve survivability and operability with a fullscale hot fire test.
title: Development and Demonstration of an On-Command, Variable Thrust, Axial Pintle System for Tactical Rocket Motors

abstract: This Phase I SBIR proposal plans to first identify modeling   methodologies that are applicable to real-time data acquisition.   Information agents will be developed to discover and isolate   discrete and continuous features within materials process data.   Process discovery implemented through the information agents will   allow the continuous features of a process to be identified and   grouped into episodes via the discrete features that segment them.   Encoding real-time data into a given modeling methodology will be   the primary consideration used in determining the suitability for a   modeling method.  Then the InfoScribe data acquisition system will   be used to demonstrate sensor-actuator connectivity on a target   process.  Following the application of material process data   acquisition, preliminary identification testes will be performed to   characterize and distinguish process noise.  Noise   characterization will be implemented as the inverse of process   characterization that is utilized by many process control tuning   methodologies.  Information agents will observe process actuation   parameters for categorized features and correlate them to dependent   process parameters to characterize the noise in a given materials   process system.  The proposed in-situ material process modeling   capability will be designed, implemented and evaluated in a Phase   II follow-on SBIR program.
title: Automated Data Acquisition for In-Situ Material Process Modeling

abstract: InfoTech Enterprises, Inc. (InfoTech), proposes to study the feasibility of a submarine compartment arrangement tool in which NAVSEA developed databases will determine the application of 3D CAD graphic design rules within a networked environment.  The underlying technique will implement a generalization of K.S. Ful's pattern grammar concept which results in generalized 3D CAD graphic rewrite rules.  Such rules are evaluated by specially modified forward and backward inferencing processes, which also support conventional symbolic inferencing, thereby introducing control by the NAVSEA databases.  This class of inferencing mechanism does not restrict constructions to a predefined set of graphic objects, and is therefore more general thana put object based approaches.  However objects can be introduced into through rule evaluation, which incorporates the advantages of an object oriented CAD system.  The proposed approaches to be less computationally expensive than simultaneous equation solution based geometric constraint solution methods due to the effect of rule compilation in which a determinate order of graphic object instantiation is established prior to use of the rule during forward chaining.  However, the proposed  technique is less general than those techniques with respect to the geometric  conditions that can be constructed.  Part of the feasibility study will consider  generalization of the approach in the context of, maintaining the potential  speed advantages.  The geometric situations which are handled by this technique are characteristic of the submarine compartmentalization problem, but also characterize major aspects of the building plan generation problem.  A solution to either problem is directly applicable to the other knowledge domain.
title: Database driven 3D Compartment Arrangements

abstract: We propose to develop a novel electronically steered MMW antenna for mobile aircraft to Milstar communications terminals. The device proposed, a new type of all-solid-state scanner, would provide for much higher beam steering rates than mechanical scanners and be less complex than phased arrays. A terminal employing the device would allow a user to rapidly log-on to a moving military communication satellite from a moving platform such as a tactical aircraft. Operation from a moving platform is made possible by a newly discovered antenna beam scanning technique. The new technique offers sub-millisecond scan times, narrow beam widths, and operates over a wide range of wavelengths. In particular, antennas using this technique would have a high rate of response, allowing for compensation of dynamic changes in platform orientation to be compensated for in real time. These antennas would eliminate the necessity for stationary antenna pedestals, and allow the user to log-on to a satellite system and establish a communications link from a moving airborne platform. By allowing platform movement, the terminal would provide increased immunity from electromagnetic counter measures and from attack. In general, the new beam scanning technique promises significant advances in MMW beam control with greater system reliability and lower cost.
title: NOVEL ELECTRONICALLY STEERED ANTENNA FOR AIRCRAFT-MILSTAR LINKS

abstract: We propose a novel, electronically steered, MMW terminal for mobile vehicle-to-satellite communication networks.  The terminal is based on a new type of all-solid-state antenna which provides much higher beam steering rates than mechanical scanners with much less complexity and cost than phased arrays.  This terminal will allow a user to rapidly log-on to a military communication satellite from a moving platform such as a land vehicle, ship, or aircraft.  Operation from a moving platform is made possible by the new antenna which offers sub-millisecond scan times and allows for compensation of dynamic changes in platform orientation to be made in real-time.  By allowing platform movement, the terminal will provide increased immunity from electromagnetic counter measures and attack.  The project would develop a low profile, conformal antenna with wide scan angle.  Laboratory feasibility of the antenna technique has been shown from 20 to 110 GHz, demonstrating that it  will work at the technically important frequencies of 20 and 44 GHz to be used for Milstar 2 down-link and up-link connectivity.  It has been shown that performance is unaffected by frequency hopping and the ability to track from a randomly moving platform has been demonstrated.  There promises to be a significant advance in MMW beam control with a high potential for a breakthrough in communication system performance.  Anticipated Benefits:  Initial benefits of this technology for the DoD mission are in the areas of communications from moving platforms, radar for closed loop fire control, secure communications, and concealed weapon detection.  Potential commercial uses include on-board vehicle radar, monitoring airport traffic, and concealed weapon detection.
title: Novel Electronically Steered Terminal for Vehicle-Satellite Networks

abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is a 6 DOF    tracking device for virtual environment applications based on a  patented wireless positioning technology.  Realization of such a  system will provide a fast, accurate and long range HMD tracker  to meet military training demand.  The objective of Phase I is  to demonstrate technical feasibility of such a system, and to  lay solid ground for building a prototype model in Phase II.   The proposed system consists of three portable signal  transmitters mounted on a helmet, and at least four relay  stations in a 3D coordinate system.  RF signals emitted from the  portable signal transmitters are received by the stations.  The  position and orientation of the helmet are then determined by  TDOA and dynamic calibration method.  The proposed system is  expected to have wide applications virtual reality and other  HMDs.
title: A RF Head-Tracker

abstract: Metal matrix composites (MMCs) are the proposed replacement materials for the ferromagnetic parts that exist in an outboard engine.  MMCs have specific stiffness properties 2 to 4 times that of aluminum alloys, steel, and titanium, while having equal or greater specific strength.  The resulting parts are extremely light weight yet robust enough to handle high strength applications typically reserved for steel, such as connecting rods, wrist pins, and crankshafts.  The technical objectives of Phase I are to: (1) demonstrate cost effective near-absolute net-shape MMC engine components that will contribute to making a "magnetically invisible" outboard using the MIT licensed pressure infiltration casting process; (2) prove feasibility of improved engine performance and efficiency by reducing mass of rotating engine parts; (3) determine magnetic components and rank them based upon magnetic signature contribution; (4) evaluate performance and cost to identify appropriate material and manufacturing processes.  A MMC connecting rod will be demonstrated to reduce mass and eliminate magnetic signature. All other contributing magnetic sources will be examined.  In the option phase, cost and performance of replacement materials will be evaluated.  BBN Laboratories, experts with marine acoustics and vibration control, will provide consulting on potential benefits of MMCs.
firm: METAL MATRIX CAST COMPOSITES, LLC (DBA M
title: Acoustic and Magnetic Signature Reduction for Outboard Engines Using Metal Matrix Composites

abstract: Proposed here is a method by which large area, thick sectioned, whisker and particulate reinforced, aluminum matrix composites may be produced for lightweight armor applications.  The first objective of this work is to conduct preliminary process optimization producing reinforced specimens 6" by 6" by 1" thick. Aluminum alloys 5083 and 224.2 will be infiltrated into SiC whiskers, alumina particulate, and whisker/particulate preforms. Reinforcement loading will vary between 10 and 55 volume fraction. Specimens with graded volume fraction will also be produced. Material characterization will include tensile testing, microstructural evaluation, and ballistic testing to determine the most promising alloy-reinforcement combinations for further examination.  Concurrently, with the first objective, the second objective of this work is to adapt a 30" diameter by 5" long pressure infiltration apparatus capable of casting 18 composite parts, 12" by 12" by 2" thick in a single run.  After promising materials are identified and the large pressure vessel is ready, at least 6 parts of at least 12" by 12" by 2" thick will be delivered for ballistic evaluation.  The final objective of this work will be to demonstrate that these large section composites may be produced at low cost.
firm: METAL MATRIX CAST COMPOSITES, LLC (DBA M
title: Advanced Pressure Infiltration Casting of Thick Section Al Matrix Composites for Armor Applications

abstract: A microsphere containing flame retardant coating for textiles is proposed.  All components in the coating system play a role in the overall protection of potentially combustible fabrics.  Organic and inorganic flame retardants, a smoke suppressor and a charring agent suitably encapsulated in microspheres form our flame retardant system.  These microspheres are then dispersed into an acrylic flame proofing emulsion vehicle which was designed for use with textiles.  Thus, every component of the flame proof coating provides a specific function in protecting the fabrics to which it is applied.  The initial work will consist of preparing separate microspheres from the individual components.  Different ratios of the microspheres will be dispersed in the flame retardent vehicle in order to ascertain the effectiveness of each component in controlling flame spread.  The coated fabrics will be tested according to ASTM specifications.  The microsphere compositions which show the best results in these test will be reformulated so as to combine all of the flame retardent components into the same microsphere.  The multi-component microspheres will then be dispersed in the same vehicle and flame tested.  The results will be compared to determine if the multi-component microspheres offer any specific advantages over the individually compounded microspheres.
title: Methanol-Tolerant Cathode Catalysts for Direct Methanol Fuel Cells

abstract: Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC) are foreseen as the choice power source for electric vehicles; more immediate battery replacement applications exist in both civilian and military markets.  Low cost of methanol and its high energy density as well as inherent safety are the reasons why there is such a great interest in this power source.   One of the major technical challenges in the development of DMFC is the deleterious influence of methanol on the oxygen cathode.  Methanol permeating through the membrane establishes a mixed potential at the cathode, thus lowering the cell voltage; in addition, methanol may also poison the cathode catalyst.  Therefore, it is desirable to develop a cathode catalyst that will be selective towards oxygen in the presence  of methanol.  The overall objective of this program is to develop nanostructured transition metal cluster compunds of the type Mo/Ru/Se.  Several variations of this class of compounds will be synthesized and characterized.  Their performance towards oxygen  reduction in presence of methanol will be assessed both in half cells and in fuel cells.
title: Methanol-Tolerant Cathode Catalysts for Direct Methanol Fuel Cells

abstract: Society is currently plagued by the disposal of post consumer plasti  c waste  products which represent 30% by volume of the National solid waste stream.  The Navy has particular problems when a vessel is at sea with several thousand  men consuming foods and beverages contained in plastic. The plastic waste  volume becomes both a sanitation and storage problem. At sea, dumping is no  longer permitted due to the potential pollution, destruction of sea life. A  novel technique to reduce this particular type of long lived waste is the  Solvent Based Plastics Recycling Process (SBPRP), in which large volumes of  waste plastics are directly reduced five hundred percent in volume and  converted to a moldable or extrudable material. Recent results based on  extensive experimentation and testing have shown that solvent reduced post  consumer waste plastics yield a highly durable product comparable in strength  characteristics to a hard wood. By modifying the process IRC has developed a  concrete-like material with one-half the density of concrete (75 lbs/cu. ft.)  and greater compressive strength (32,000 psi). The object of this endeavor is  to demonstrate the effectiveness of the solvent based plastics recycling  process and to show that direct reclamation of the densified form of plastic  waste produced by the Navy's Plastics Processor can be economically  attractive. Early experimentation has indicated that little washing and no  separation is required prior to shredding comingled plastics. Unlike current  plastics recycling techniques, the SBPRP appears to be very attractive  economically, environmentally and socially.
title: RECYCLING SHIPS' PLASTIC WASTE

abstract: The proposed SBIR research targets the development of advanced   optical diagnostic instruments for the study of turbomachinery.   The Particle Imaging Velocimetry technique is proposed for   instantaneous, two-dimensional velocity measurements and flowfield   visualization in turbomachinery.  The instrument proposed for use   in this study will be designed specifically to address the problems   associated with studying unsteady transient flowfields in the   Compressor Aero Research Facility at Wright Laboratory.  This   optical-based non-intrusive instrumentation will also serve as a   test bed for the further extension of other advanced optical   diagnostic techniques to the study of complex turbomachinery   flowfields.
title: Dev of Adv Laser Diagnostic Techniques for Turbomachinery Applications

abstract: RESEARCHERS ARE DESIGNING, CONSTRUCTING, AND EVALUATING A 3-12 M NARROWBAND LIGHT SOURCE BASED ON AN OPTICAL PARAMETRIC OSCILLATOR/OPTICAL PARAMETRIC AMPLIFIER PAIR (OPO/OPA), CONSISTING OF ZNGEP2 CRYSTALS THAT ARE PUMPED BY A TUNABLE OPO.  THE TUNABLE OPO, WHICH IS ITSELF PUMPED BY A ND:YAG LASER, PROVIDES A NOVEL METHOD NOT ONLY FOR PUMPING THE ZNGEP2 OPO, BUT FOR PROVIDING AN ADDITIONAL OPTION FOR TUNING AND FOR CHARACTERIZING IT.  MEANS FOR NARROWING THE LINEWIDTH OF THE ZNGEP2 OPO ARE BEING EVALUATED.  SINCE FEMTOSECOND AND PICOSECOND ND:YAG LASERS ARE AVAILABLE, THE SYSTEM CAN LEAD TO AN ULTRAFAST TUNABLE IR SOURCE.  THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO PROVIDE THE TECHNICAL BASE FOR THE MANUFACTURE OF A LONG SOUGHT 3-12 MUM TUNABLE LASER SOURCE.
title: TUNABLE NARROWBAND LONG WAVE INFRARED LIGHT SOURCE

abstract: ZNGEP2 SINGLE CRYSTALS HAVE OUTSTANDING NONLINEAR AND OPTICAL PROPERTIES THAT MAKE THEM THE MOST ATTRACTIVE CANDIDATE FOR OPTICAL PARAMETRIC OSCILLATORS AND AMPLIFIERS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TUNABLE LASER RADIATION IN THE 2.5 TO 13 M REGION.  THE DEVELOPMENT OF ZNGEP2 CRYSTALS HAS BEEN HAMPERED BY SYNTHESIS METHODS THAT ARE NOT CAPABLE OF PROVIDING THE REQUIRED PRECISE STOICHIOMETRY AND HIGH PURITY, BY AN ANOMALOUS ABSORPTION BETWEEN 1 AND 3 M, AND ALSO BY A LACK OF DATA ON THE PRESSURE-TEMPERATURE-COMPOSITION OF THE ZN-GE-P SYSTEM.  RESEARCHERS ARE USING A NEW TWO-TEMPERATURE SYNTHESIS TO PREPARE ZNGEP2 SAMPLES, OF VARYING COMPOSITION ABOVE AND BELOW THE EXACT STOICHIOMETRIC POINT AND CHARACTERIZING THEM WITH RESPECT TO ACCURATE ELEMENTAL COMPOSITION, OPTICAL TRANSMISSION, LATTICE CONSTANTS, RESISTIVITY, AND PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY.  AN IMPORTANT OBJECTIVE IS TO UNDERSTAND THE NATURE OF THE 1 TO 3 M ABSORPTION.
title: SYNTHESIS AND CHARACTERIZATION OF HIGH PURITY ZNGEP2

abstract: Wavelets are the topic of much excitement in mathematics, engineering, and scientific circles, particularly in the field of data compression. We propose to develop a suite of advanced wavelet compression algorithms especially designed for low frequency acoustic and transient signals. These algorithms will incorporate the latest wavelet transforms, including wavelet packets and cosine packets. The techniques will be designed to maximize classification performance. To develop and evaluate the data compression methods, we will build a realistic testbed of low frequency acoustic and transient data. This testbed includes both real data, extracted from the "Hudson Canyon experiment" and simulated data generated from the KRAKEN model. A range of methods will be used to evaluate the effects of compression, including a mode coupling analysis and assessment of the misclassification rate. This research proposal involves a partnership between the StatSci Division of MathSoft, Inc. and the Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) of the University of Washington. StatSci has an active wavelet and signal processing research group, and in 1994, released the S+WAVELETS software toolkit for wavelet analysis. APL is one of the leading research centers emphasizing Navy applications in ocean science, acoustics, and engineering.
title: Feature-Based Compression and Browsing of Tactical Data

abstract: The work proposed for Phase I has been formulated with the objective of defining a basis for  developing and fielding a computer based tool for selecting and performing trade studies on  multimedia.  The basis will be drawn from theory,  research, and successful cases of multimedia  instruction directly related to Navy applications.  The proposed Phase I effort will focus on  specification, grounded in sound pedagogy and practicality, of an intelligent tool that guides  practitioners, whatever their level of  instructional and media technology or content domain  expertise, through the analysis process to determine and document how, when and for whom  the multimedia can be used, its logistic impact, life-cycle parameters, and estimated  costs/benefits.
title: Development of Improved Human-Computer Interfaces for Electronic CLas

abstract: Some polymers exhibit Seebeck coefficients that are 100 to 1000 times higher than those of semiconductors used in today's thermoelectric devices.  Unfortunately these polymers have low electrical conductivity that results in a figure-of-merit, ZT, that is much lower than do the conventional semiconductors.  Attempts to increase the conductivity of polymers by doping or micro particle addition have not proven successful in increasing ZT.  The addition of low volume concentrations of nanophase metal particles (size ranging from 5 to 100nm) to conventional insulating polymers greatly increases the electrical conductivity without increasing the thermal conductivity of the composite.  The anomalous conductivity enhancement demonstrated by nanophase metal particles may allow non-shunting conductivity increase in polymers with high Seebeck coefficients that would result in a high ZT for the composite material.  Since theory does not allow prediction the transport properties of such nanophase materials, ICE, Inc. proposes to attempt to prepare a composite of a nanophase metal in an intrinsically conducting polymer that is known to have a high Seebeck coefficient.
title: Nanophase Composites as a Route to Pratical High ZT Polymer Thermoelectric Materials

abstract: Members of the genera Rickettsia and Ehrlichia are obligately intercellular, arthropod-borne bacteria which are distributed either worldwide or in defined geographic areas.  Several are human pathogens; the severity of infection ranges from inapparent to fatal.  Initiation of preventive measures and appropriate treatment depend on awareness of the infectious agent's prevalence within a given region.  Assessment of disease incidence would benefit greatly from commercial availability of a simple, standardized,l and economical diagnostic test suitable for use in unsophisticated settings.  A dipstick (DS) test meeting these criteria, produced by Integrated Diagnostics, is being used in several countries for detection of antibodies to pathogenic rickettsiae.  We propose to develop a similar test for recognizing ehrlichia infections, whose importance is only now being appreciated.  Phase I comprises (1) developing methods for bulk cultivation of 2 ehrlichia species (e. sennetsu, E. chaffeensis) and purification of these plus human granulocytic ehrlichia and (2) antigen validation studies to determine the ehrlichia DS suitability for further testing.  Phase II will encompass distribution of ehrlichia and rickettsia DS in a regionally appropriate manner for extensive field testing of their sensitivity and specificity.  Accumulation of data in Phase II will permit refinement and tailing of the DS to meet the specific needs of a geographic area.
title: Advanced System for Worldwide Surveillance of Rickettsial Disease Antibodies

abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project proposes a novel, proprietary, micromachined, Coriolis-based, mass flowmeter.  This flowmeters possesses many desirable features, including:  significantly lower cost, direct mass flow measurement, direct fluid density measurement, small sensor size, low power consumption, measurement of low mass flow rates, high sensitivity, high accuracy fast response time, small fluid flow volume, simple fabrication process, batch fabrication capability, excellent stability, and compatibility with on-chip electronics.  In addition, since this device measures mass flow directly, it is not sensitive to fluid conditions, such as temperature, pressure, density, viscosity, and conductivity.  Furthermore, unlike thermally-based mass flowmeters, this devices does not generate heat or local high temperature points in the environment under measurement, making it suitable for applications such as fuel monitoring for combustible engines.  This device can replace many conventional mass flowmeters used in applications such as semiconductor manufacturing.  Furthermore, due to its small size and low power consumption, this device is also best suited for both portable, and battery-operated applications.  The major objectives of Phase I are (1) to design and fabricate prototype devices and, (2) to characterize and test them.  Achieving these objectives is necessary in order to prove the technical feasibility of this new concept.  Anticipated Benefits:  Because of its sought-after features, this device has the capability of capturing many existing markets, as well as creating new markets, including, aerospace, defense, active control systems for combustible engines, portable personal health monitors, wearable soldier monitoring systems, miniature weather monitoring stations, microinstrumentation clusters, biomedical, automotive, industrial, building industry, and manufacturing/processing applications.
title: A Micromachined Coriolis-Based Flowmeter for Direct Mass Flow and Fluid Densitv Measurement

abstract: During previous work, Intelligent Automation Incorporated (IAI) has demonstrated the feasibility of a design aid for the design and implementation of built-in on-line self-test and diagnosis of electronic systems. With this technology, Navy systems could include integral components which perform built in on-line test and diagnosis, and which display (on the board itself) either a good indication, or display the most likely failed component or group of components. The results of this development will be more accurate and lower cost diagnosis of faulty Navy systems. We have named our system the Microelectronics Display (MIDIS) Design System because using our approach, each printed circuit card or similar aggregation of components will have an on-board display of its status, including a specific identification of failed components or groups of components. Despite the initial success of our preliminary work, there is a great deal of work still required to validate our approach in more general cases than we have done thus far, and to extend the MIDIS Design System to a fully functional system. The current MIDIS Design System does not handle transient or intermittent errors. We believe that the theory and framework of the MIDIS Design System are more than adequate to support this capability, but a great deal of research and development is still required. Since there are far more cases of transient and intermittent error that hard errors, and since these types of errors are often very difficult to diagnose, this capability of MIDIS is particularly important. Our preliminary experimental system handles only the simplest signal types and although the results are encouraging, under the work herein proposed we will expand these signal types sufficiently to provide a more valid proof of concept. Many other enhancements and extensions to the current "toy" system are required before we have a fully usable product.
title: Scalable High Performance Computing Using Autonomous Agents

abstract: Intelligent Automation, Incorporated is developing a new innovative approach to concurrent product-process development.  The resulting system will also allow integrated development of production planning and scheduling, including external supplier integration.  Our approach is based on the paradigm of autonomous agents.  The work herein proposed focuses on improvements and extensions to the "Intelligent Agent Infrastructure (IAI)" already partly developed by Intelligent Automation, Incorporated (IAI), and on development of standards to allow consistent creation, operation, and evaluation of these systems.  Specific innovations proposed for the infrastructure include a "subscription book", to extend the concept of inheritance from objects to agents, and market driven computation resource allocation integrated with the other communication and interaction between agents.
title: Autonomous Agents for Distributed Problem Solving, Planning and Control

abstract: A dual Distortion Product Otacoustic Emission (DPOAE) and Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)automated newborn hearing screener will be developed. This application focuses on new noisecancellation techniques for DPOAE acquisition in order to increase the reliability and testing bandwidthbelow 1500 Hz. Currently available systems provide limited noise rejection capabilities whichsubstantially increase testing time by increasing the number of sweeps necessary. These noise reductiontechniques utilize a primary microphone and two additional microphones to acquire internal and externalnoise reference signals. These techniques include: Adaptive Noise Cancellation (ANC), SpectralEnhancement Averaging (SEA) and Adaptive Wiener Filtering (AWF). Each of these methods will betested with a full complement of noise sources and each will be compared to standard averaging (5A)with artifact rejection. One set of single sweep data will be collected from 12 newborns in order tocompare directly the various processing schemes. Phase I testing will focus on 5 frequencies, 0.5, 1,1.5, 4 and 8 kHz. The performance of the processing strategies will be evaluated using ANOVAtechniques using as dependent variables the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and number of sweeps requiredto reach an SNR level.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Dpoae System with Advanced Noise Cancellation Techniques

abstract: DoD spends billions of dollars each year on specialized trainers.   We propose to exploit recent developments in multimedia   communications, the Internet, agent technology, distributed   simulations, domain independent knowledge representations and   intelligent tutoring systems to reduce the cost of provide   authoring tools for building training systems.  We propose to   employ standard languages, start-of-the-art software engineering   techniques, and to exploit the "information Superhighway's" World   Wide Web (WWW) to (1) reuse existing distributed resources, (2)   employ existing knowledge stores and (3) utilize the interfaces of   existing tools for those of our student diagnostic and modeling   systems.
title: Multi-Agent Tool for Effective Network-Based Training Systems

abstract: In this Phase I SBIR proposal, IntelliSense Corporation proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of integrating optical, electronic, and mechanical functions in a single low cost, compact and reliable inertial system. The baseline system consists of an integrated optics gyroscope and a micro-opto-mechanical accelerometer. The accelerometer uses optical techniques to measure the response of the silicon micromachined flexures to acceleration. In Phase I, we will demonstrate feasibility of a silicon integrated optics gyro by performing a rigorous design and performing several manufacturing steps. In Phase II, we would optimize the gyroscope concept demonstrated in Phase I, produce and evaluate the performance of the gyro and integrate it with a micromachined accelerometer in a monolithic inertial measuring unit (IMU) system. The micromachined optoelectronics gyro proposed has two unique technological features: (1) a sensitive measurement technique using ring resonators and (2) unique material processing for the waveguide formation. The resonator technique has the advantages of high performance with low sensitivity to thermal variations, non-homogeneity and material residual stress. The processing technology uses micromachining to produce miniature, low cost and batch fabricated devices compatible with standard integrated circuit (IC) processing.
title: Microfabricated Gyro Using Opto-electronics

abstract: A CAD framework to assist process engineers and designers in   conceptuallizing, designing, simulating, and optimizing the   performance of microelectronic devices is proposed.  It will   manage extensive manufacturing data, data representing the   description of a system, and thermal, electronics,   electromagnetic analysis results.  It will enable use of   multiple and inter-related simulation engines for development of   microelectronics devices.  It will be ready for integration of   additional tools by using an open architecture.  The Phase I effort will be to extend the architecture of   IntelliSense's current CAD tools (for microelectromechanical   systems) to include microelectronics devices.  This extension will   call for the development of the necessary tool-independent   open-architecture framework in order to link the physical   description of a microelectronic device with simulation and   behavioral models such as thermal, electrostatic and   electromagnetic analysis.  Activities will include benchmarking the   architectgure using common and standard processes.  In Phase II, the framework developed in Phase I will be used as a   blue print to implement the core technology of the microelectronic   CAD proposed.  Commercialization will be through the existing   market channels of IntelliSense.
title: Integrated Physical Modeling and Analysis of Microelectronics

abstract: We will research and develop custom overlays for the intelliKeys alternative keyboard in orderto improve language-arts education for students with physical or learning disabilities. These customoverlays will be designed specifically to meet the physical and cognitive access needs of students withdisabilities. They will be created to meet the response requirements for several existing literature-basedand computer-aided language-arts curriculum activities. We will research the effectiveness of theseoverlays. Our Phase I feasibility effort will focus upon developing a set of tools to document the effectsof custom overlays on two measurable phenomena: 1) student performance and, 2) the social andaffective perceptions of the students and teachers involved in the activities. Data will be collected inthird and fourth grade classrooms during computer-aided language-arts activities. Activities will beconducted in small group formats using established cooperative learning strategies where students withdisabilities are included. We will compare student performances when using an IntelliKeys keyboard witha custom overlay designed specifically for the activity versus using more traditional keyboard options.We expect to demonstrate 1) our ability to evaluate the effects of the custom overlays, and 2) thatwell-designed overlays improve student performance and classroom attitudes.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Language Arts Keyboard Overlays for Disabled Students

abstract:
40222                                            November 6, 1996
Intercat Development, Inc.

Mixed metal oxide sorbents are being developed for hot gas desulfurization for advanced integrated gasification combined cycle (IGCC) power systems.   Recent testing of a leading sorbent formulation, a spray-dried zinc titanate, in a pilot-scale transport reactor indicated a need for improved attrition-resistance of the sorbent in order to reduce fines generation.  Conventional clay binders, such as bentonite and kaolinite, used in the preparation of current spray-dried zinc titanate sorbents do not provide the needed strength to withstand the extremely harsh mechanical stresses generated in a transport-type fluidized-bed reactor.  This project will  utilize a novel clay-phosphate binder for zinc titanate compositions to produce highly attrition-resistant zinc titanate microspheres by spray drying, while maximizing their chemical reactivity.    Phase I  will demonstrate the applicability of this novel binder technology to zinc titanate sorbents in a laboratory-scale spray dryer. The sorbents prepared using this technology will be characterized to identify those formulations that meet the performance targets defined by the supplier of the transport reactor technology. One superior sorbent will be tested for 10 cycles of absorption regeneration to demonstrate its cyclic absorption/regeneration performance and attrition resistance. 

Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:   Once the production and use of these highly attrition resistant and reactive zinc titanate sorbents  are demonstrated, the operational cost of advanced IGCC plants should be reduced due to reduction in sorbent requirements. The near-term use of these sorbents should be in the Pinon-Pine Clean Coal Technology Demonstration Project jointly funded by DOE and the Sierra Pacific Power Company.
title: An Attrition-Resistant Zinc Titante Sorbent for a Transport Reactor

abstract: A study will determine the feasibility of using a digital-library system for computer-system vulnerability information.  The system model will draw upon advances being made in multi-agency NII digital library research projects, library science techniques being developed for digital media, and standardized WWW technologies.  Technical objectives include determining how best to: 1) catalog and classify vulnerability data for ease and accuracy of browsing, searching, identification, and access, 2) design the accessioning and curation process to ensure scalability and durability of the library, and 3) canvass vendors and other stakeholders to determine what security measures would be necessary to permit vendors and other stakeholders to contribute sensitive information.  Areas of investigation will include selection of vulnerability taxonomies, and tools and methodologies for:  managing catalog records, extracting indexes from catalog records, managing workflow, maintaining authority records for classification schemes (taxonomies), information browsing, and information finding agents which can search through catalogs entries, indexes, abstracts, and documents.  Compliance with library science reference models and catalog standards will be emphasized, as well as GILS compliance to support linkages with other federal information services.  Alternatives will be analyzed for reliability, cost-effectiveness and ease of use and operation.
title: A Digital Library of Computer-System Security Vulnerabilities

abstract:
41302                                           November 19, 1996
International Radiation Detectors, Inc.

This project will design state-of-the-art silicon photodiodes for use as particle detectors in plasma diagnostics.  These devices will be very sensitive to low energy particles.  Owing to their unique characteristics, the proposed devices are expected to have better than 1 keV energy resolution around room temperature.  Phase I will fabricate these diodes and evaluate their response to 1 keV to 40 keV hydrogen, nitrogen, helium, argon and neon ions at Los Alamos National Laboratory. If the developed diodes are found to be useful as expected, the Phase II effort will fabricate these devices with an integrated front end amplifier for higher energy resolution.

Commercial Applications and Other Benefits as described by the awardee:  The diodes should be extremely useful for detection of low energy ions and neutrals from fusion reactions and also from solar wind. They should also be useful for analysis and identification of radioactive species for nuclear facility safety monitoring and environmental remediation. Other applications include electron microscopy, spectroscopy and electron beam lithography.
title: Silicon Detectors with 40 Ao Entrance Window for Low Energy Ions and Neutral Particles

abstract:
40209
International Solar Electric Technology (ISET)


Copper indium diselenide and related compound semiconductors are important photovoltaic materials.  Although copper indium diselenide type devices are the highest efficiency thin film solar cells ever produced, they are not yet commercially available because of difficulties associated with the costly processing schemes employed in the fabrication of these devices.  This project will  develop and demonstrate a lower cost, more robust, large area processing technique for copper indium diselenide photovoltaics.  In Phase I,  absorber layers with controlled composition will be deposited on metal coated glass substrates, and efficient solar cells will be fabricated on these absorbers.  In Phase II,  the processing technique will be further refined to fabricate large area photovoltaic modules.


Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:  Successful completion of this project  will provide a new low-cost processing option for the manufacture of copper indium diselenide type solar cells and  accelerate the commercialization of this very important photovoltaic technology.  Thin film solar cells and modules have a wide range of terrestrial and space power generation applications.
title: Large Area, Low Cost Processing for CIS Photovoltaics

The modified system will be sensitive to effects of           team composition and individual difference variables, and           will be designed to simulate requirementsss for team member           cooperation. abstract:
41179
Ion Physics Corporation

Electrostatic precipitation is used extensively to control the emission of particulate matter from oil or coal burning power stations.  However, an unsolved problem concerns the efficient removal of fine particulates (particles of 5 ¿m in diameter and below) from the flue gas stream.  Particles of this size are important because the human respiratory system does not effectively filter them and they pass readily into the throat and lungs.  The rate at which particles can be removed from the gas stream depends on their average velocity towards the collecting plates. This velocity, commonly referred to as migration velocity, is strongly dependent on particle size. Smaller particles, because of their much smaller charge, have a substantially lower migration velocity.  One way to overcome this problem is to agglomerate particles, thus forming larger and, consequently, easier to collect particles. Particles will agglomerate by finding each other simply through random thermal motion. Unfortunately, this process is too slow to be of practical value in electrostatic precipitators. This project will develop a variant of bipolar agglomeration, where one fraction of the entrained particulates are charged with one polarity and the remaining fraction to the opposite polarity.

Commercial Applications and Other Benefits as described by the awardee:  Successful completion should show high removal rates of fine particles from flue gas with reasonable time and volume requirements. The process could provide a cost effective means for new and existing plants to control fine particulates.
title: Control of Respirable Particulate Matter from Flue Gases

abstract: Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) has become an important technique for determinimolecular weights of peptides, proteins, glycoproteins, and oligonucleotides. Time-of-flight mass spis normally used with MALDI because all of the ions made by the laser pulse can be detected. Althougand has sub-picomolar sensitivity, the mass resolution and mass measurement accuracy are limited. Resuccessfully coupled MALDI with an IonSpec externalion source Fourier transform mass spectrometer. Eand ultra-high mass resolution were achieved for [Arg8]-vasopressin, neurotensin, melittin, and a nuFor bovine insulin the isotope cluster peaks were baseline resolved (M/ delta M1/2 = 90,000), and thaccuracy was 0.002 percent (20 ppm), which is more than an order of magnitude better than with TOF-Mof the new MALDI-FTMS method is excellent, as demonstrated by a mass spectrum for 100 fmol of a trypprotein. The aim of this grant application is to develop a low cost, compact FTMS instrument that caspecialists in lifescience laboratories. In Phase I, they will redesign and repackage all the electrinstrument. Instead of a research-grade instrument that can perform any conceivable experiment, theinstrument will be made specifically for MALDI. Improved reliability and serviceability will be achiFTMS electronics in a single chassis.

title: Low-Cost Maldi-Fourier Transform Mass Spectormeter

abstract: Good insitu tools exist for measuring temperatures and thickness   during epitaxial thin film growth.  In contrast, almost no   technique gives information on surface elemental composition in   real time.  We propose an extremely simple experiment which can be   performed with an ion source little more complex that a noble ion   sputter gun.  This technique can very accurately measure surface   coverages of light elements on heavy or heavy elements on light   using low energy beam doses of less than 0.1 nA/cm2.  Thus layer   composition control during the growth of nitride thin films such   as GaN and InN will be aided.
title: Novel Pulsed Nitrogen Source Diagnostic for GaN Thin Film Stoichiometry Control

abstract: The innovation is a real-time algorithm and processor that will increase the nominal resolution of an imaging array.  IR EMSPS will use a standard 2D infrared imaging array and readout, increase its effective pixel count by 16X, and increase the spatial sampling frequency of the array by 16X.  IREMSPS is based on a "microscan", that moves the image in sub-pixel increments, and a scene-based pointing device, that will allow the output of each pixel to be placed into one of many "output" pixels.  An added benefit of this autonomous positioning is that the scene may be motion stabilized, allowing for additional processing to take place such as temporal integration.  The Phase I goal is to create a system simulation of the algorithm, test it against many expected conditions.  This will also include algorithm optimization to minimize required processing power, and an examination of the hardware architecture that will be required for Phase II prototyping.
title: Image Resolution Enhancement Using Microscan and Scene-based Pixel Steering (IR EMSPS)

abstract: A compact (less than one-tenth cubic inch) covert camera with digital data capture is proposed to satisfy military, DEA, and FBI surveillance requirements.  The product, which will be developed during Phase II, integrates an imaging active pixel sensor with ultra low power analog and digital signal processing electronics and Flash memory into a small assembly which can be powered for up to one year by a small battery.  3D Silicon, the vehicle which enables this system level miniaturization , is comprised of a number of very thin (25 micrometers) heterogeneous integrated circuits laminated together implementing an event actuated video camera with digital data compression and solid state data storage.  Playback of the the recorded imagery is commanded by a bi-directional IR data link.  Data compression is accomplished by SIMD/MIMD processors integrated within the stack.  During Phase I, the individual elements of the Compact Covert Camera will be demonstrated at the integrated circuit level.  The Phase II/III partnerships will be perfected during Phase I with a local police force, a military user, and a federal law enforcement agency.  Anticipated Military Benefits/Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development:  The camera can be carried covertly by law enforcement officers or emplaced in rooms, parcels, luggage or vehicles.  The FBI has an airport surveilance requirement.  Military special operating forces have many relevant applications and will be the primary performance drivers.
title: Covert Compact Camera

abstract: Irvine Sensors Corporation proposed to develop a technique to assemble a memory equal to 20 Gbits in an area of less than 0.5 cubic inch.  This memory would provide storage for up to 2.5 seconds of video for a 1000 x 1000 pixel camera sampling at 1000 Hz.  This is to be accomplished by a three pronged advance in today's technology.  First, state of the art 64 Mbit DRAM will be utilized in the stack.  Second, the number of layers in the stack will grow from approximately 80 to 160.  Third, each layer in the stack will contain a pair of 64 Mbit DRAM for a combined 128 Mbit per layer.
title: Covert Compact Camera

abstract: The proposed innovation is a highly accurate azimuth sensor package that will be small, light, rugged, simple to operate, and offer accuracy better than 0.5 degrees.  The HI-MINS is a six-axis inertial measurement unit that provides linear acceleration and angular velocity information.  Through time integration velocity, hence position, and angular direction relative to an inertial reference coordinate can be determined.  Additional instruments on the vehicle will enhance the accuracy of calculation to account for current flow and other unpredictable disturbances under water.
title: High Accuracey Miniature Inertial Navigation system (hiMINS)

abstract: The objective of this project is to design a fractual object based image database system which enables video insertion into real time simulation systems.  A cost/benefit analysis of the design will be performed to determine the utility of implementing the design in Phase II.  Requirements for the Fractal Object Database System will be determined in consultation with the Sponsor and from interaction with commercial providers with simulation hardware and software.  The fractal coding methodology which the Proposer has developed and commercialized for imagery will be extended to image objects.  A test set of image objects will be extracted.  A verification demonstration of the fractal object methodology to extract, code and render image objects will be provided.  The final report will explain the fractal object methodology, the proposed fractal object database system and its application to simulation systems.
title: Fractal Object Database System for Simulation Environments

abstract: Electronics shielding weight savings of 30 percent for Air Force spacecraft are possible using composite materials instead of aluminum boxes and aluminum skin.  Designs balancing polymer matrix materials and high atomic number materials will be generated for Air Force missions in various orbits.  Composite materials will be fabricated and then tested to verify radiation hardness and shielding of electronic components.|  Benefits:  Launch cost savings of up to $2M per launch can be realized for geosynchronous satellite missions.|
title: Lightweight Composite Spacecraft Shielding

abstract: The overall objective of this effort is to prototype, validate and successfully commercialize a professional quality process analysis tool kit for affordability (PATA) that includes packaging, training, and support.  The PATA will consist of easily used tools that enable life cycle performance, cost and schedule affordability analyses and trades, both during the R&D phase of technology development, and during subsequent technology transition to acquisition and/or support.  The Phase I goal is to design, develop, and demonstrate a prototype of the PATA that is based on an R&D Affordability Framework Reference Model (AFRM) and the user requirements of our strategic partners (The Science and Technology Directorate of the Air Force Material Command, and Texas Instruments).  The demonstration will also help verify specific domain architectures and external application interfaces.
title: A Process Analysis Tool Kit for Affordability (PATA) Supporting the R&D Process

abstract: The proposed Phase I effort will determine optimal characteristics for a counter-communications radio frequency weapon (RFW).  There are three primary elements to the optimization process.  One element is the RFW itself, consisting of a power supply, radiation source, and antenna.  They must be integrated into a robust package of minimum weight and size.  Another key element in the optimization process is the radiated waveform, characterized by power density at a given range, frequency or frequency content, pulse repetition rate, duty cycle, and modulation.  The power density necessary to produce an effect can vary by orders of magnitude as the characteristics of the RFW waveform are changed.  Optimizing the RFW waveform can significantly reduce size and weight of the weapon, increase its useful range and its operating time.  The proposed optimization process actually starts with the third element, identifying vulnerabilities common to many radio types that are difficult to counter.  Once target vulnerabilities are identified, the RFW waveform will be optimized.  This determines requirements for the REW, which is optimized to minimize size and wight.  This systematic process has proven to be more successful than starting with a given RF source and trying to find system susceptibilities by trial and error.
title: C2W Applications for Radio Frequency Weapons

abstract: Owing to the proliferationof chemical and biological weapons by countries not friendly to the US, and attack is an increasing possibility.  In the event of an attack the accurate prediction of the dispersal of chemical and biological agents is necessary for minimizing the effects of their release.  In the event that is becomes necessary to detroy the plants which fabricate or store these weapons, the most efficient method of completely destroying the facility should be undertaken.  In order to predict the dispersal and destruction of chemical and biological agents, JAYCOR proposes to develop a computer model containing all of the issues that are involved in the control and spreading of these materials.  These include missile-to-missile intercept, a missile attack which can spread the materials over the ground and into the buildings, dispersal in a buildings' rooms and ventilation system, and the in-situ destruction of the agents.  JAYCOR will use its EITACC computer program as the basis for this effort.  EITACC has all of the required elements for predicting the destruction and dispersal of chemical and biological agents.  These include complex geometry, compressible flow, two-phase flow, chemical reactions, and turbulence.
title: CFD-Multiphase Flow

abstract: K2T, Inc. proposes to design and demonstrate an interactive system capable of reconstructing 3-D models from ordinary video image sequences.  Although many people are currently working in the field of shape from motion, no one has yet developed a commercially viable system for reconstructing 3-D models from videotape.  The objective of this Phase I research is to design such a system.  The system we propose is based on recent advances in image understanding theories, in particular the factorization method and related modeling by videotaping work being done at Carnegie Mellon University.  The result of this Phase I effort will be a complete object oriented design specifying tasks such as feature extraction and tracking, shape motion reconstruction, 3-D modeling, representation conversion, and attribute recovery.  A small portion of this system will also be implemented and used to evaluate the feasibility of the approach.  The feasibility study and the system design will provide a foundation for Phase II development.
title: An Interactive System for 3-D Modeling from Videotape

Kalsi Engineering, Inc.

Reliable, long-life, high-speed bearings with high thrust are needed for roller cone bits used in hard rock drilling. Even though incremental increases in bearing performance and life have been achieved over the past decades, the goal of dramatically increasing speed and life under the high bit loads necessary for hard rock drilling has proven to be extremely difficult.  Continued improvements in bearing materials have resulted in only modest increases in the bearing life of the roller cone bits.  This project will develop a high-speed bearing design concept that has the potential to significantly increase both the speed and load limits of the bearings used in roller cone bits.  Estimated cost savings can be 15 to 20 percent if the bit life can be doubled.

Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:  Successful completion of this project should result in a reliable, long-life, high-speed bearing with high thrust capability for roller cone bits used in hard rock drilling.  It will significantly improve efficiency and reduce the cost of drilling hard rock wells.
title: High Speed Bearing for Roller Cone Drill Bits Used in Hard Rock Drilling

abstract: Our research will develop reagents and procedures for detection of nucleic acids fromLeishmania. Leishmania are grouped broadly into the New and Old World species. Throughout tropicaland subtropical regions of the world, leishmaniasis is a serious public health concern. Effectivetreatments exist; yet, diagnosis is difficult, owing to low abundance of parasites in the peripheral blood.Consensus probes and primers will be designed, based upon published mini circle kinetoplast sequences.Primers will incorporate inosines and mixed base positions to support amplification of Old and New Worldspecies. Non-radioactive microliter plate assays have been developed for performing hybridizationanalysis of amplified DNA. These methods, together with simplified DNA extraction and amplificationtechniques will be adapted to a consensus DNA probe assay for Leishmania using laboratory strains.In Phase II, these procedures will be refined and extended to detection in clinical specimens.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Development of DNA Probe Test for Leishmania

abstract: High strength steel alloys (300M) used in navel aircraft engine and landing gear components are found to be highly susceptible to fatigue cracking, induced by the cyclic loading these structures are subjected to in service. Stress-induced cracking is found to initiate due to improper grinding and machining of the parts during fabrication. There is critical need for nondestrucive techniques which can detect both cracking and potential crack nucleation sites within these components. Current NDE procedures using MPI methods suffer from limited sensitivity to these cracks, on account of the coatings used above the ferromagnetic steel alloys for corrosion resistance. A novel hybrid probe and instrument is proposed to simultaneously detect both subsurface residual stresses and stress-induced cracking in coated and uncoated ferromagnetic structures. Modifications to make these dual measurements are proposed on probe designs developed recently by the authors to measure residual stresses in anti-friction bearings. In Phase I, we will develop these modifications and demonstrate system capabilities through simple experiments. A prototype for a portable, commercially viable system is planned to be developed and delivered in Phase II.
title: Magnetoeleastic Probes to Detect Subsurface Cracking/Residual Stresses Beneath Coatings in Ferromagnetic Materials

abstract: KaZaK Composites Incorporated (KCI) has teamed with Northrop Grumman Corporation and Dastin Associates Company to develop and demonstrate technology and manufacturing prcesses for productio of composite rod with embedded fiber optics for smart structures appl.lications.  During the course of Phase I, the program team will conduct laboratory studies of the basic properties of Fujikura PANDA Polarization Maintaining optical fiber, with the intent of establishing acceptable processing conditions.  Various composite materials and manufacturing methods compatible with these processing conditions will be considered and compared. Demonstration parts will be produced using the pultrusion process to fabricate long lengths of rod with embedded optical fiber.  This rod will be evaluated to assure that the pultrusion process has notdegraded the optical properties of the embedded fiber. Alternative techniques, including UV and E-beam curing will be considered.  The proposed effort will benefit from previous SBIR work of this program's PI involving the use of pultrusion to fabricate graphite/epoxy tubes with embedded piezoelectric actuators and  a variety of embedded sensors.  The sponsor of this earlier SBIR work, the Air Froce PHillips Lab, will participate inthe proposed program via an existing Cooperative Resarch and Development Agreement already in place with KCI.
title: Design and Fabrication of FOG-M Composite Guidance Bobbins with Embedded Fiber Optic Strain Sensors
